information: Economic challenges and trade policy are key sources of market uncertainty. Tariffs imposed by the Trump administration have led to downward revisions of corporate earnings expectations. A Goldman Sachs model predicts that a 5% increase in tariffs could lead to a 1-2% decline in S&P 500 earnings per share. Sevens Report notes that even with reduced trade tensions, the base level of tariffs will remain much higher than in January, acting as a barrier to growth and a driver of inflation. Analysts at Barclays have expressed skepticism about whether there is enough momentum in U.S.-China trade discussions to avoid a U.S. recession.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: About 1 month (until the S&P 500 close on Fri May 30, 2025)
forecast.status_quo_outcome: A modestly higher month-end close in May versus Apr 30 (Yes), consistent with typical monthly base rates and recent buy-the-dip behavior
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Hawkish Fed tone on May 1 and/or a hotter-than-expected CPI/PPI mid-May push yields higher; tariff headlines escalate or broaden; several mega-caps miss or guide cautiously, triggering de-risking and a lower May 30 close versus Apr 30
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Fed reassures on policy (no tightening bias) and inflation prints are benign; mega-cap earnings largely beat with supportive guidance (AI/semi strength persists); any early-May wobble is bought and the index grinds higher into month-end
forecast.rationale: Base rates favor a slight positive: historically the S&P 500 finishes up in roughly 55–60% of months, and May specifically is near the lower end of that but still above 50%. With only a one-month horizon, inertia and mean-reversion effects often dominate unless a clear macro shock hits. Earnings season continues through early-to-mid May, and a handful of large-cap results can disproportionately support the index if they come in strong. If April finished soft or volatile, lighter positioning and buy-the-dip tendencies slightly improve the odds of a rebound into month-end. Offsetting that, trade policy and inflation risks cap upside. As summarized by the research assistant: tariff increases under the current administration raise uncertainty and can pressure multiples via inflation and EPS headwinds (e.g., a 5% tariff increment shaving ~1–2% off S&P EPS per Goldman Sachs). Sevens Report’s point that the new baseline tariff regime is structurally higher suggests a persistent drag, and Barclays’ skepticism on US–China progress keeps recession risk in the conversation. These factors justify not pushing the probability far above the base rate. Why not higher: macro policy risk (Fed tone, sticky inflation), tariff-related EPS/multiple pressure, and elevated valuations imply asymmetric downside to negative surprises. Why not lower: resilient large-cap earnings, ongoing AI/semi momentum, and the monthly positive base rate keep the odds above 50%. What would move me up: a dovish-leaning Fed on May 1, cooler CPI/PPI/PCE data, and clean beats/guides from the mega-caps (would raise into low/mid-60s). What would move me down: upside inflation surprises, renewed tariff escalation headlines or concrete measures with near-term earnings impact, a broad set of mega-cap misses/guidance cuts, or a sharp rise in yields (could drop to the mid-40s). Given these, I put extra weight on the status quo/base-rate outcome and set a modestly-above-even probability.
